top_comment.text: Viva Cuba! Viva Fidel!﻿
top_comment.author: Guerrillero Martin

comments.text:
+nsziszo  I am sure you tell the truth. I had a very similar experience 
growing up in Puerto Rico. It's also been happening in USA for a long 
timeToo. Worse now than ever. Watch out what you post here or on facebook, 
E mail and phones are also tapped. Good luck
comments.author: lulu turull

comments.text:
+lulu turull Hi Lulu! If you have a dream to go there, give it a try. You 
might find the differences in the two countries economical difficulties 
then, and also what it means not to have freedom of speech and constantly 
watching your opinion because you might get into jail if it differs from 
the "official" views.

I'm aware of the size of the Puerto Rican population living in the US. I 
have lived in a Boricua neighborhood in NY for a while and also had many 
co-workers from your country. So I could get accounts of their problems, 
but also  got accounts of cuban immigrants now living in Europe. And their 
stories were much worse, mainly because (besides the ecconomical problems) 
their true self, their thinking, speaking, their open opinion was 
controlled. 
  
(Disclaimer: I myself have not lived in neither of the 2 countries, so I 
can only rely on the stories of the immigrants that left these two 
countries.)
comments.author: nsziszo

comments.text:
+nsziszo Half of Puertorricans live out of their own beloved country and we 
don't have a dictator. We have worse education and  health care than Cubans 
who live in Cuba. Some times I wish I would live there; really I do. Maybe 
One day, when I don't have so many responsibilities and if I am still 
healthy. I will go. Love
comments.author: lulu turull

comments.text:
Vivan los cubanos donde quiera que estén!! Vivan los que están en la Isla 
pasando trabajo y vivan los que tuvieron que abandonar su patria por el 
simple hecho de pensar diferente... Fidel pues tendrá que rendir cuentas 
cuando le llegue la hora por el daño que causó, la división y el odio que 
sembró en nuestra tierra....Vivan los cubanos!!!!! Que lo que la ideología 
separó, el arte lo vuelva a unir!!....

*Playing For Change*﻿
top_comment.author: Kyle Rojas

comments.text: Thanks, Lina. Glad you enjoyed it.
comments.author: Kyle Rojas

comments.text:
I am a big fan of the idea and execution of Playing For Change.  Honestly, 
I think the background reflects the diaspora of the Cuban culture. A large 
number of the Cubans of Hemingway's old Havana put roots down in Miami as a 
result of the Cuban Revolution.  Neither the song nor the culture solely 
resides in the beautiful old barrios of old Havana anymore.
comments.author: Kyle Rojas

comments.text: "Playing For Change" has a lot of beautiful songs and performances
comments.author: Linh Hong

comments.text:
Yo soy un hombre sincero :) What a beautiful performance, but ai ai ai 
those ugly concrete buildings of Miami spoil it somewhat. More of those 
colourful houses and gardens, more of those old Havana houses in which the 
ghosts of Hemingway and "Our man in Havana" can feel at ease... Let the 
music go hand in hand with the right background...
comments.author: Benoit Vanhees

top_comment.text:
*Great article on Progreso Weekly about PFC's "Guantanamera"!* Luis Conte, 
PFC musician and renowned Cuban percussionist calls the video *"a project 
of humanity and emotion, of brotherhood among Cubans, of friendship and 
love for Cuba. We are from that place, and music binds us together.”*  Papa 
Orbe Ortiz, PFC Band member also from Cuba says that *“not since the Buena 
Vista Social Club have so many Cuban musicians gotten together. It is an 
encounter between musicians in Cuba and outside, where there is no room for 
politics or anything else that isn’t music and love.”_*

Read more here: 
http://progresoweekly.us/75-cuban-musicians-join-play-guantanamera/

Get your copy of #PFC3 Songs Around The World here: http://bit.ly/1mgP4HK﻿
top_comment.author: Playing For Change

comments.text:
Spanischer Originaltext
Yo soy un hombre sincero,
de donde crece la palma,
y antes de morirme quiero
echar mis versos del alma.

Deutsche Übersetzung
Ich bin ein aufrichtiger Mensch
von da, wo die Palme wächst,
und bevor ich sterbe, möchte ich
mir meine Verse von der Seele singen.

Mi verso es de un verde claro
y de un carmín encendido.
Mi verso es un ciervo herido
que busca en el monte amparo.

Deutsche Übersetzung
Mein Vers ist von hellem Grün
und von entflammtem Rot
Mein Vers ist ein verwundeter Hirsch
der im Gebirge Zuflucht sucht

Cultivo una rosa blanca,
En julio como en enero,
Para el amigo sincero
Que me da su mano franca.

Deutsche Übersetzung
Ich ziehe eine weiße Rose heran,
im Juli wie im Januar,
für den ehrlichen Freund
der mir seine offene Hand reicht.

Con los pobres de la tierra
quiero yo mi suerte echar.
El arroyo de la sierra
me complace más que el mar.

Deutsche Übersetzung
Mit den Ärmsten der Erde
will ich mein Schicksal abwerfen.
Der Bach im Gebirge
erfreut mich mehr als das Meer.
comments.author: Monika Zwiefelhofer

top_comment.text: Amazing project! I wish I had money to help!﻿
top_comment.author: recon smith

comments.text:
+recon smith ¡Ay Dios! Cómo es la cultura de estos gringos. Lo primero que 
dicen frente a lo que sea es "I had money to help!". Todo lo ven y reducen 
al dinero. No se necesita dinero para apoyar, Mr. Smith. Se necesita tener 
alma internacionalista y no imperialista para apoyar. ¡Viva Cuba libre!
comments.author: Luis Alberto Pacheco Mandujano

comments.text:
+recon smith, Thank you for your kind words in support of Playing for 
Change! We would love to have you involved in promoting positive change 
through the universal language of music. The following are the ways I think 
you might like to become involved:1. Make sure you sign up to become a PFC 
Member to receive updates and exclusive content, and 'like' our Facebook 
page as well. We would love for you to spread the word in your community as 
well, whether it be sharing a post or hosting  a PFC video screening 
night!2. Keep an eye out for the PFC Band next lives, and check out our 
brand new album, PFC3 Songs Around The World, featuring 185 musicians from 
31 countries!3. Lastly, if you or any of your friends are interested in 
supporting the PFC Foundation directly, you can check out the different 
ways to get involved here, and join us for this year's Playing For Change 
Day on September 19th! PFC Day is a global day of action during which 
musicians from all over the world perform on stages, street corners, 
schools, yoga studios, and cafes to bring music into the lives of young 
people and to promote positive social change. The event was created in 2011 
so that everyone can get involved and become a part of our global 
community. PFC Day 2014 saw over 400 amazing events in 60 different 
countries, each raising funds for the PFC Foundation’s music schools and 
programs! Please send any questions and/or inquiries to 
info@playingforchangeday.org.  Thank you for helping to create peace and 
positive change through music!One Love,PFC Team
comments.author: Playing For Change

comments.author: Marcos Vidal

comments.text:
+Marcos Vidal Marcos, aunque estoy de acuerdo que la repression en Cuba es 
intolerable, esto no es el foro para indagar sobre la realidad que el 
comunismo y el socialismo son ideas politicas que culminan en favoritismo 
hacia los que rigen el poder y el ciudadano comun pierde sus derechos 
humanos. 
Here's my translation:
Marcos, although I am in agreement that repression in Cuba is intolerable, 
this is not the forum to discuss about the realities that communism and 
socialism are political ideologies that culminate in favoritism toward 
those that rule and where the common citizen looses all human rights.
We must applaud these Cubans that put aside political beliefs and got 
together to sing "our song" and the words of Cuba's greatest poet Jose 
Marti. I am also a musician, and if they would have contacted me, I would 
have been proud to have been a part of sharing in a verse of Guantanamera:
"Cultivo una rosa blanca,
para el cruel que me arranca
el corazon conque vivo,
para el amigo sincero,
que me da su mano franca, 
nardos y rosas cultivo,
cultivo una rosa blanca."
Jose Marti.

comments.text:
Que levante la mano quien no ha aplaudido al terminar el vídeo. Fantástico, 
gran labor, mi más sincera enhorabuena y gracias por la publicación.
comments.author: Gato Land

comments.text: P.S.  Listening and singing ~  again!  MWAH!
comments.author: Jessan Dunn Otis

comments.text:
Just this afternoon, I was singing along, at concert level, windows opened, 
as I traveled up I-95 North, back to Providence.  This is one of *the* best 
renditions of Guantanamera I've ever heard.  Thank you, as always, +Playing 
For Change.  #PlayingForChange
comments.author: Jessan Dunn Otis

comments.text: Que Buenoooo Arriba Playing -for Change
comments.author: Hugo Gonzàlez

captions.text:
I am a truthful man
from the land of the palm tree
And before I die I want
to share these verses of my soul
in July the same as in January
in July the same as in January
who offers me his hand in friendship

who tears out the heart
by which I live

who tears out the heart
by which I live

I cultivate neither
thorns nor bitter leaves
With the poor of the Earth,
I want to cast my fate
With the poor of the Earth,
I want to cast my fate
pleases me more than the sea
I know of a deep sorrow
among the ones without a name
Don't put me in the dark

(Listen to me, party-goer)
Don't put me in the dark
I am good, and like the good

I will die with my face to the sun
(I’m telling you)

In the distant countryside,
in any street,
on a hill, on a plain,
You who listen to my song

title: Guantanamera | Playing For Change | Song Around The World
